title: 107_hr1789
content: Exemption from income tax for state-created organizations providing property and casualty insurance for unavailable property coverage. Exemption from income tax for state-created organizations providing property and casualty insurance for unavailable property coverage. Amendment to section 501 of the Internal Revenue Code to include associations created before January 1, 1999, by State law, operating exclusively for this purpose. The assets of the association must only be used for specific purposes, including satisfying liabilities, investing in authorized investments, paying administration expenses, and making remittances. The association's assets are used for specific purposes such as paying claims on policies, purchasing reinsurance, and supporting programs for natural catastrophic events. State laws allow the association to levy assessments on insurance companies or policyholders to fund deficits. The association's assets are used for specific purposes like paying claims, purchasing reinsurance, and supporting programs for natural disasters. State laws permit the association to levy assessments on insurance companies or policyholders to fund deficits. The plan of operation of the association must be approved by the state's officials or legislature, and its assets revert to the state upon dissolution. An entity receiving remittances from the association is treated as part of the association. An entity created before January 1, 1999, receives remittances from an exempt association to pay insurance claims and support disaster programs. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a special rule for organizations described in section 501(c)(28) regarding unrelated business taxable income. A transitional rule states that no income or gain shall be recognized by an association changing its status to that of an association described in section 501(c)(28). The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
